Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Sectarianism Without Borders: Big Data and Experimental Analyses of Transnational Sunni-Shia Conflict

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Abstract
Sectarian violence in the Middle East and Arab World have increased to their highest levels since the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980s. Violent conflict between Sunni and Shia sects can be found in a number of countries throughout the Middle East. While a large volume of qualitative literature address such this topic, we lack rigorous quantitative studies into the factors that lead to such violence, along with factors that serve to escalate or mitigate sectarian tensions in the region. Relatedly, scholars know little about the effects of heightened Sunni-Shia hostility on citizens' political attitudes and behaviors in the affected regions. Drawing on research in political science and social psychology, the PI will conduct an empirical examination of the causes and consequences of sectarian animosity in the Arab World, paying particular attention to those factors that may lead to reductions in the levels of violence. To gain a deeper understanding of the causes of sectarian conflict, the investigator utilizes a unique data set comprised of Twitter and Google Trends data, real-time event data, public opinion polls, as well as results from a lab experiment. Substantively, this project will offer empirical insights into the dynamics of a precarious source of conflict and violent extremism, with key ramifications both for regional stability and global security.

Technical Abstract
To examine the causes of sectarian tensions, the PI will use Twitter and event data to explore how exogenous violent events lead to the escalation in sectarian hostility, and the role political and religious elites play in this process. The PI proposes to administer a series of household survey, timed to coincide with Shia religious holidays to assess the causal effect of elevated sectarian tensions on attitudes toward democracy, authoritarianism, and extremism. Additionally, the PI will utilize an experimental design to test the degree to which emphasizing common threats and experiences of victimization might serve to reduce outgroup prejudice among Sunni and Shia Muslims in two ways. First, by conducting the experiment on a sample comprised of students, and secondly, through the use of a Twitter experiment. By adopting innovative methodological approaches that build upon and help reconcile existing theories of intergroup relations, this project makes important contributions to both political science and social psychology. Furthermore, by helping to identify causes and consequence of sectarian hostility, and by providing empirically validated approaches to combat such tensions, this work is poised to provide valuable insights to policy makers and academics alike.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011, as protests swept the Arab World and authoritarian regimes began to topple, journalists, academics, and policymakers were abuzz with optimism that the so called “Twitter uprisings” or “Facebook revolutions” would usher in a fourth wave of democracy. With social media platforms at their disposal, many argued that Arab citizens were newly empowered to demand change, and the region’s dictatorships and monarchies would be unlikely to survive for long. But everyday citizens were not the only ones empowered by these new tools. Elite actors—including clerics, royal family members, politicians, military leaders, and well-known extremists—also flocked to social media, often harnessing these platforms for decidedly undemocratic purposes.

Seven years after the self-immolation of a Tunisian fruit seller sparked mass protests throughout the region, the Arab Spring has devolved into a long and bitter Arab Winter. From the resurgence of authoritarianism and sectarian strife, to vehement Islamist-secular polarization, the fallout from the Arab Spring has resulted in hundreds of thousands of deaths and the displacement of millions of refugees. A diverse body of qualitative and quantitative research has examined the power and limitations of social media during the 2011 protests. But what role are these platforms playing in the conflicts and crises that have been left their wake? In particular, how are elite actors using social media to incite conflict and consolidate power? And what can social media data teach us about the role of elites in intergroup conflict more broadly? Using datasets of hundreds of millions of Arabic language tweets, online and survey experiments, as well as more traditional data sources, my dissertation presents original theory and offers new empirical insights into how elites exacerbate and mitigate intergroup conflict in the post-Arab Spring period.

Chapter 1 explores when and to what degree elites provoke intergroup conflict. I argue that when elites use hostile and divisive rhetoric as a tool for ideologically outbidding opponents, they also run the risk of empowering extremist groups and fomenting domestic instability. Religious and political elites therefore walk a fine line between inciting intergroup tensions to attract support from their constituents and tamping down hostility when it emboldens their extremist rivals or threatens the status quo. I test this theory using Saudi Twitter data to offer real-time measures of mass and elite behavior on the same platform. As the theory predicts, I find that while Saudi clerics and royal family members both instigate and spread derogatory rhetoric in the aftermath of foreign episodes of sectarian violence, they are less likely to do so following domestic anti-Shia mosque bombings.

 Building off of the findings presented in Chapter 1, Chapter 2 demonstrates that despite their role in inciting intergroup conflict, elite actors are actually uniquely positioned to combat prejudice and intolerance in the online sphere. Using experimental evidence from a nationally representative survey experiment in Lebanon and an online experiment across the Arab Twittersphere, I find that messages priming common religious identity with endorsements from religious elites are particularly effective in reducing the spread of sectarian hate speech, as well as support for such rhetoric.

 Finally, Chapter 3 explicitly explores the role that social media is playing in elite exacerbation (and mitigation) of intergroup conflict in the post-Arab Spring period. I argue that social media has democratized communication networks, giving everyday citizens unprecedented access to information from a wide variety of elites and everyday citizens. Drawing on intergroup contact and elite cute theories, I assess the relationship between network diversity—engaging with both Islamist and Secular elites—and political tolerance in post- coup Egypt. Taking advantage of the real-time networked structure of Twitter data, I find that greater network diversity is not only associated with lower levels of intolerance, but that spending an additional year in a diverse network results in a significant decrease in the use of intolerant rhetoric over time. This suggests that in addition to creating “echo chambers,” which may be used by elites to exacerbate conflict, social media may also afford the opportunity for citizens to be exposed to a greater diversity of ideas, increasing their tolerance for outgroups.

This dissertation makes three primary contributions: First, it develops original theory and uses new data sources to address fundamental questions in the political science literature on the role of elites in exacerbating and mitigating intergroup conflict. Second, given that the vast majority of research on social media and politics in the Arab World has focused on the 2011 protests and their immediate aftermath, it provides new perspective on the role that social media is playing in the conflicts and crises that have emerged in the wake of the Arab Spring. Finally, it delivers new insights for academics and policy makers alike on opportunities for reducing prejudice, intolerance, and extremism in the Arab world and beyond.
